comments.text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:6.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/6.0
Build ID: 20110811165603

Steps to reproduce:

Removed a DOM element.


Actual results:

DOMSubtreeModified fired on an ancestor element before the element was removed.


Expected results:

Per the specification, DOMSubtreeModified should fire after the element is removed, the same way it does in Gecko versions < 6

comments.raw_text:
Attaching testcase.

Reports the number of childnodes after a DOMSubtreeModified event. Firefox 4 and 5 both report 0, while Firefox 6 reports 1.

comments.author: kkumari@softvision.com
comments.creator: kkumari@softvision.com
comments.text: Is this something that is still being investigated or fixed?
comments.raw_text: Is this something that is still being investigated or fixed?

comments.text: I'd rather not make any changes to mutation events until there is a proper spec agreed upon by all major browsers. Right now there's lots of subtle differences and it's not clear who's right since the spec is very vague.
comments.raw_text: I'd rather not make any changes to mutation events until there is a proper spec agreed upon by all major browsers. Right now there's lots of subtle differences and it's not clear who's right since the spec is very vague.
comments.creator: jonas@sicking.cc
comments.author: jonas@sicking.cc

comments.creator: jonas@sicking.cc
comments.author: jonas@sicking.cc
comments.raw_text: Any changes that we make at this point is likely to break more content than it fixes, so we should only do it if we're confident that we won't have to change it again, and that it aligns with other browsers so that everyone is pulling in the same direction.
comments.text: Any changes that we make at this point is likely to break more content than it fixes, so we should only do it if we're confident that we won't have to change it again, and that it aligns with other browsers so that everyone is pulling in the same direction.
